projects.notes: Two chunks of color in an Oddball blanket for charity. :)
projects.name: my bit of the Cville Oddball Blanket, Part Deux

projects.notes:
CO 54
breakdown: 7 for each 1x1 ribbed side (pkpkpkp), 20 for each top/bottom flat area.

Body of sleeve:
K in pattern (20, pkpkpkp, 20, pkpkpkp) for length of DS, mine went approx. 50 rows. At top, switch to k1p1 rib - on first pass around, decrease once however you like within each ribbed section (now 52 around). Continue around, cast off at desired length.

Duplicate Stitched Boo:
I duplicated a few rows of the sprite pattern, and fudged a little besides, because my rows-to-columns ratio was not square. The image is thus not the exact Boo sprite. To make the little Vs created by knit stitches a little more square, in the dark colors (black, red) I ‘capped’ them by sewing a line of yarn across each stitch that met another color. (Hard to explain in text; see image.)

Bottom of sleeve:
A pseudo not-quite-kitchener stitch to close the bottom.
projects.name: DS Sleeve - Boo

projects.notes:
Gray section = Paton’s and Lamb’s Pride, simple 4x4 squares.
Blue section = Valley Yarns, simple 4x4 squares.
Black section = some mystery 100% wool from the stash, 4 knit by 4 purl, zig-zag pattern.
projects.name: my bit of the Cville Oddball Blanket 'Big Bruiser'

projects.notes:
CO 54. Breakdown: 7 for each 1x1 ribbed side (pkpkpkp), 20 for each top/bottom flat area.

Body of sleeve:
K in pattern (20, pkpkpkp, 20, pkpkpkp) for length of DS, approx. 50 rows. At top, switch to k1p1 rib - on first pass around, decrease once however you like within each ribbed section (now 52 around). Continue around, cast off at desired length.

The stitched-on sprites aren’t the actual pixel images - I had to duplicate some rows (and fudge a bit besides) because my stitches are wider than they are tall.

After sitting in a project bag for ages I picked this baby back up and finished the body of the bag on 1-17-11. Now for the duplicate stitching.

All done, very happy with it. :)
projects.name: DS Sleeve - Star / 1up Mushroom

projects.notes:
• CO 120
  • k2 p2 around FOREVER (6 inches). Hat has no folded brim - keep knitting however many extra inches you want to be able to fold up.
  • decrease as follows:
  1. k2, p2tog, k2 p2 to end
  2. k2, p1, k2, p2 around
  3. k2, p1, k2, p2tog
  4. k2, p1
  5. k2tog, p1, k2, p1
  6. k1, p1, k2, p1
  7. k1, p1, k2tog, p1
  8. k1, p1, k2tog
  9. k1, p1, k2, p, k
  10. k, p, k2tog
  11. k1, p1
  12. k2tog
  13. k around

Hat will fit just about anybody widthwise, 120 is really too much, but the rib keeps it snug enough to stay on - go longer (7 inches, maybe) for larger-headed folks, these were for a pair of kid sisters.
projects.name: Hats for the Girls (2x2 rib)

projects.notes:
1. CO 32 in round, knit 2x2 rib to bottom of thumb.
  2. Instead of knitting next to k sts, put them on a safety pin, turn work. Continue 2x2 rib until you bump back into 2 pinned sts.
  3. Turn work and go back the way you came.
  4. CO 2 over the thumb gap when you get back to it.
  5. Keep going around in a 2x2 rib until you hit bottom of fingers, bind off.
  6. Pick up for thumb (including 2 pinned sts), k around until desired length reached, bind off.

Tada.

2. Instead of knitting next to k sts, put them on a safety pin, turn work. Continue 2x2 rib until you bump back into 2 pinned sts.
3. Turn work and go back the way you came.
4. CO 2 over the thumb gap when you get back to it.

breakdown: 7 for each 1x1 ribbed side (pkpkpkp), 20 for each top/bottom flat area.

Body of sleeve:
K in pattern (20, pkpkpkp, 20, pkpkpkp) for length of DS, approx. 50 rows. At top, switch to k1p1 rib - on first pass around, decrease once however you like within each ribbed section (now 52 around). Continue around, cast off at desired length.

projects.name: DS Sleeve - Owl

projects.notes:
I made this pattern up as I went. I had issues with extra/missing stitches the second time around - don’t follow this pattern! When I make my next pair, I’ll figure out what went wrong, and try to clean it up.

Where Color A is green, and Color B is gold;
And this is the chart:
XOOOXX
OOOOOX
XOOOXX
XXOXXX

CO 42 (worsted weight yarn)
k1, p1 around * 5 in Color A.
Begin following chart (k only)
Continue until there are 5 solid diamonds in Color A.

Thumb hole:
Turn work, come back purling from whence you came. When you reach the point where you originally turned the work, turn it again, knit back. Do this a total of 9 times (last time should be a k row.)
You may CO 6 over the thumb gap for another diamond (I did in this pattern, but I wouldn’t again, requires big palms).

Continue in pattern until you reach desired length.
k1, p1 in Color A.

Thumb:

  1. pick up (pu) and knit 2 on a single needle.
  2. pu 1, p across the 2 you picked up last row, pu again (4 total)
  3. pu, k2tog (using just picked-up stitch), k2, k2tog w/ last stitch and a pu’d stitch (still 4 total)
  4. pu, p4, pu (6 total)
  5. pu & k2tog, k4, k2tog w/ a pu’d stitch (still 6 total) Now the thumb has a ‘lip’ so it won’t stick out perpendicular with the mitt.
  6. pu around thumb hole to 24 total. I did k2 p2 here but I meant to do k1 p1 …
  7. Knit in pattern to desired length.

I later separated the ribbed green part into finger-slots because I made the palm a little too high. I didn’t really knit these separators; I took a tapestry needle and threaded through the mitt from palm to back of hand in three times (three strands), and then took more yarn and wove through these three to make a sturdy little … thing. It needs a photo, it’s really hard to explain!

Someday when I make this into a real pattern I’ll get rid of these awful notes.
projects.name: Diamond Mitts

projects.name: LRZ & SVZ Towels

projects.notes:
CO 54
breakdown: 7 for each 1x1 ribbed side (pkpkpkp), 20 for each top/bottom flat area.

Body of sleeve:
K in pattern (20, pkpkpkp, 20, pkpkpkp) for length of DS, mine went approx. 54 rows. At top, switch to k2p2 rib - on first pass around, decrease once however you like within each ribbed section (now 52 around). Continue around for 12 total rows, cast off on 13th row in pattern.

Duplicate Stitched Mushroom:
I followed the sprite’s pattern, 1 st per pixel. Sprites are 16x16 - so there should be 2 sts on either side. Notice poor mushroom is flat - I did not attempt to correct the fact that the knit stitch is not really square (it’s wide).

Duplicate Stitched Bullet Bill:
I duplicated a few rows - now the stitch-to-pixel ratio isn’t 1:1, but he doesn’t look squished, at least.

Bottom of sleeve:
We’re going to knit 4 sts wide along the length of the opening, making the bottom of the case, picking up stitches on the sides as we go to connect them.

Hold sleeve so that the ribby sides of the sleeve are vertical (as if the DS was on its side). Take the bottom ribbed section and pick up the 4 purl stitches.

Starting on the right, knit across 4 and turn work.

We’re going to pick up a stitch with our in-use needle every round, and then knit/purl it together with the first st. When picking up sts, reach past the CO stitches, the 2nd or 3rd stitch down is good (but be consistent).

Pick up a st now that you’re looking at the purl side (5 total).

p2tog, p3. Pick up another st at end of needle but don’t purl it. (5 sts total). Turn work.

K2tog, k3. Pick up another st at end of needle but don’t knit it. (5 sts total). Turn work.

projects.notes:
I started this pink hat when I was making charity hats in Oct 2010. But the event ended with this hat still on the needles, and it waited patiently in a basket for more than a year.

Today I needed my size 7 needles, and lo and behold, there they were, underneath this hat. So I finished it! But I don’t like pink, so the hat will have to wait, again, this time for a recipient. I have been calling it “the horrible hat” because it was painfully ugly in its first incarnation, I was knitting two strands together, and had some red in there, too, and it just looked awful. Now I think it actually looks nice, if still way too pink for my own personal taste.

projects.notes:
From image, hats go…

A B C D
E F G H
I J (in pic #2; used a different pattern for these two)

… here I lost track! I made another hat before Nov 1st, the black and gold striped hat. But I already forget when I cast on and off. It’s okay - it’s for the program co-ordinator, Mark, so it doesn’t really count as a charity hat anyway. :)

projects.notes:
For the base hat I used Justine Turner’s great Aviatrix Baby Hat pattern. Instead of one flap with a button, I just did two half-flaps down the sides that don’t connect, because I’m not confident I can attach a button secure enough for tiny baby fists.

The goggles, those ubiquitous steampunk accessories, I just made by crocheting, no pattern.
projects.name: Steampunk Baby Hat

projects.notes:
For the base hat I used Justine Turner’s great Aviatrix Baby Hat pattern (v2!). Instead of one flap with a button, I just did two half-flaps down the sides that don’t connect, because I’m not confident I can attach a button secure enough for tiny baby fists.

The goggles I just made by crocheting, no pattern.
projects.name: Steampunk Baby Hat #3

projects.notes:
I knit Justine Turner’s adorable Aviatrix Baby Hat for a friend’s daughter and another friend jokingly said he wanted one for himself. As he possesses a head of truly epic proportions, I took this as a challenge.

Believe it or not, I almost entirely stuck to the pattern - I just used big needles (5s or 7s, I forget now) and held the bulky yarn double-stranded to get the size. My only alteration was that I worked one less section on the top, as adult heads are not so round in the back as babies’. The hat’s massive.
projects.name: Giant Aviatrix Hat

projects.notes:
Aunt Diane made the same mistake others before her and remarked that she liked the baby aviatrix hat on a cute kiddo (Ava) that she wanted one herself. DONE.

Modifications: I messed up with the two needle sizes. You’re supposed to use the bigger needle for the body and a smaller one for the ribbed top/bottom, I did the opposite (7 for rib, 6 for body). I also kept the top/bottom ribbed parts the same size (kept 45 sts), and didn’t decrease for the 2nd rib (it asked for 12 rows, I did 10, as I did on the first part).

To make the earflaps lay back a bit on their own, I started with 21 ear flap sts, and decreased per pattern until I had 13 sts.

  1. Now the yarn is danging on the ‘face’ side of the hat. Knit the first 7 (half + the center st), wrap the 8th, turn work, knit back across the 7.
  2. Do a normal row (with decreases). Now 11 sts.
  3. Do another. 9 sts.
  4. Repeat process from 1. Knit to center st, wrap st just beyond it, turn work and knit back.
  5. This was the width I wanted for the final flap, so I didn’t decrease. Just knit back and forth (2 rows). On face side again.
  6. Stop purling for that center st (worked in ‘stst’). Repeat process from 1 and 4.
projects.size: technically the smallest for sport weight (CO 45)

So I made a baby sweater out of them. :) Waste not want not (especially with CCC yarn!)
projects.name: Easter Jacket for Quinn (BSJ)

projects.notes:
I’m essentially done, but I might wait to do the last few rows (with buttonholes) until I know who I’m giving this to.

I finished up to the button-making row on Monday, May 30th in Trieste.

Edit 9/24/11: Finished, and was glad this was on the needles and almost done; I’m drowning in wedding knitting but I’ll be darned if baby Burdock goes sweaterless into the autumn!
projects.name: Orange Jacket for Burdock (BSJ)

projects.notes:
5 sts = inch gauge (maybe even more like 4.9 sts per inch), used the smallest available instructions (in blue on my copy, which is the Schoolhouse Press Pattern #5, A-B-C-SJ).

(I THINK I used a size 4 needle… I forget! Used one recommended in pattern, I think.)

PS: Forgot to say I had to end the ‘flap’ part prematurely because the striping wouldn’t work out otherwise. Not a big deal, I was only one color ‘off’, so the jacket is just a teeny bit shorter in the waist than a single-color BSG would be.

----- 11-23-10
So, it took me FOREVER to get those ends in. Jeez. But I finished last night, and reinforcing the buttons, and now this baby is DONE. Pics incoming.

----- 11-11-10
Finished! Now for ends… and there are a lot of ends.

----- 11-7-10
Color changes didn’t work out; increases/decreases looked super bad. :( So, trying again, this time making entire ‘ridges’ in one color like so …

CO, row 1-4 in Asparagus
5-8 in Forest Heather
9-12 in Peapod

So, 4 rows per color (I decided I wanted wider stripes) and the important part: color changes occur on ODD NUMBERED ROWS. Not even. Looking much nicer already at row 36.

----- 11-5-10
CO, row 1 in Asparagus.
Row 2 and 3 in another Forest Heather.
4 and 5 in Peapod.

So. This means that on what’s traditionally the outside of the BSJ I have two-toned ‘ridges’. The color change occurs there. Meanwhile my inside is changing very concretely. Add to this that I like the inside of the shoulder decreases more than the outside, so maybe I want to flip it? HMMM. I’ll just knit it up and whichever I like best will be the outside.
projects.name: Striped Jacket for Kyra (BSJ)

projects.notes: Love this pattern. Love this yarn. If it was big enough for me I’d be wearing it myself.
projects.name: Blue Jacket for Connor (BSJ)

projects.notes:
8-3-10 -- I’m on Chart C, which is the last chart before switching to big shawl/shawlette-specific directions, and my mom has come for a surprise visit - yikes! It’s hidden in a drawer but I want to work on it desperately! She has no idea…

8-13-10 -- So … two rows away from the end, I decided I didn’t like how the third color came in. The gray is lovely and I really like it, but it came late in the shawl, and if I could’ve ended on it I think that would’ve been fine, but instead it’s a big stripe two inches from the bottom, and I don’t like it. So. I am going to … rip it back. A lot. So sad. :(
-- update: done. 36 rows of 200+ sts apiece. OUCH.

9-8-10 -- Two rows away from the end, I realized I forgot to add the center ‘leaf’ … I just left the center row as is … but I am too tired to rip it back. Again. I think it looks fine without that leaf, so I will do a little improvisation when I get there, I suppose, when casting off. Oi. I think it will look fine, it’s just not on pattern. But I’ve ripped enough, I’m determined to finish.

9-14-10 -- I lied. I couldn’t stand it, I ripped out the 17 rows. So painful. But then I FINISHED IT, HA.
projects.name: Bitterroot

projects.notes:
A shawl and handkerchief for my friends GS and XW!

Shawl

I modified the pattern quite a bit to make the leaves come in earlier. This is what I did:

  • Chart A 1-28, repeat 9-28 again once.
  • Chart B 1-20 (all)
  • Chart C 1-8
  • Chart F 1-16, with altered row 1 (trying to make it line up with beginning of chart G, drew a picture of the chart, rav message me if you’re desperate for it!)
  • Chart G 1-16, then 1-23.

I did this a little awkwardly - in the future, just note this handy fact:

You can repeat Chart G 1-16 forever.

So if you can get yourself up to start Chart G at the point you want the leaves to come in, you can loop there until you’re ready for the shawl to end.

I finished the shawl part of this on March 2nd.

Handkerchief

Cast on 100 for the handkerchief on March 2nd, knit stockinette FOREVER on tiny little size-1 too-small DPNs (I need size 1 circulars real bad!). Body of handkerchief is 13.5” by 13.5”, edging is 5-st garter all picked up after.
projects.name: XW + GS

projects.notes:
-- 6/1/10:
Here I go, my first shawl … with Wolle’s glorious CCC (color changing cotton) in Summer Night. I’ve seen a few other Citrons with her yarn, and they come out looking so cool, I’m going for it. So excited!

Couldn’t get gauge, settled on:

Pattern gauge: 24 sts/36 rows = 4” in stockinette
My gauge: 22 sts / 28 rows = 4” in stockinette

Don’t mind if it’s smaller, as I’m going to do extra rows … am a little scared about the loss of rows, though. I hope it’s not too squished.

-- 6/17/10:
Got side-tracked helping a pal finish some afghan squares. Which turned out to have more lace than my first-ever shawl, here. Whoops. ;) With any luck, back to the shawl next week … yay. I’m still excited. It’s just starting to change color.

-- 07/17/10:
Got totally addicted to this shawl. Craziness. All done and blocked and photographed, now! I ended up using just the dark blue portion of skein 2 of the Summer Night - I wanted the edging to stay dark but I didn’t want to go through another whole skein of length. I am totally going to take the rest of that cute skein and turn it into a little accessory bag to go with my awesome shawl!
projects.name: Summer Night Citron

projects.notes:
CO 60, the Ladies Fingering size, on size 2s - the ribbed portion is fine but the body of the sock in stockinette is just a little bit too big/loose. Just a bit. Might go down a size for the next set, or buy myself some size 1 needles (I knit so loosely, but even so, 1s! So tiny!).

I bought this yarn when I was in Trieste, Italy, which is the farthest I’ve ever gone and brought yarn back! This was the shop:

Culot Di Silvia Fonda S.A.S.
Via delle Torri, 34122 Trieste, Italy
projects.name: Trieste Socks

projects.notes:
11/8/11: Finally got a picture. Renamed the project (from the innocuous ‘Boring Socks II’) to Husband Socks.

9/26/11: Secretly these are not Boring Socks at all, but Husband Socks. To be delivered to J once he becomes a husband. Just seeing the word husband here is blowing my mind, FYI. Anyway, don’t tell him, plz.

Note to self: in this pattern, I used the “women’s” number to cast on, because the last time I did the “men’s” fingering on 2s the socks came out huuuuge. This was just right.

Also, I used ”Jeny’s Surprisingly Stretchy Bind Off” which WAS surprisingly stretchy … but almost too much so. But nothing else I tried was nearly stretchy enough (eg the tubular bind off (kitchener st bind off)).

The first socks I ever made.

Guessing on the date.
projects.name: My First Socks

projects.notes:
Sparkly gift yarn from Lou, hooray!

I did a 3x1 rib for the entire length of the sock, and kept the ribbing over the top of the foot. Never in my life have I been so excited to finally turn a heel, jeez.

I originally finished, wove in ends, etc, on July 2nd, but after wearing them a bit I needed maybe a cm or two around the top of the calf, so I used up every fiber I had left casting on again around the top. Now they are perfect. And I used all the yarn!
projects.name: Sparkle Socks

projects.notes:
10-2-10 -- Done. I tried all three might-be-it reds (Bordeaux, Crimson, and Rouge), nothing matched. Bordeaux was close enough that I think the difference was just a big dye lot issue … unfortunately too big to deal with. So I did the heel and toe in black. Good enough for now, and hopefully the brother will like them anyway.

9-5-10 -- So, I ran out of yarn - and can’t find another skein of bordeaux ANYWHERE that looks enough like mine to be seamless. :( So … I ripped out up to the heel, and now I’m doing the middle of the feet in this weird slightly-different looking color. Sigh. This has been the Summer of Messed Up Knitting Projects.

Pictures of the finished socks incoming!

Loved the first pair so much I cast on another pair exactly like them! They’re really good simple/general socks, and I’m not picky, I just want wool on my feets.

Finished these in the air between Denver, CO and Philadelphia, PA!
projects.name: Boring Blue Socks II

projects.notes:
Not actually sure I started these socks in March, they’re just so that I have SOMETHING cast on to work when I’m between projects or need something boring to work on. Despite calling them boring I actually do like them, they’re nice and soft.

I bought the yarn for the a theoretical sweater but ended up thinking it was too light and lilac-y. I forget the brand … but I’m loving it for socks.

CO 44 (Ladies’ size in worsted).
projects.name: Boring Blue Socks

projects.notes:
I am in love with this yarn pattern and in love with this yarn. This is my sixth “Classic Socks” pair of socks, and the versatility of it means I am going to get a great fitting pair, no ifs, ands, or buts.

And the yarn … such a soft, thick, warm, beautiful yarn! Perhaps too good for feet - but Jason likes this color green (I am also fond of it, ahem) and he is a great appreciator of home-made socks, so I consider it a reward for his loyalty.

Notes:
CO 56 on size 2 needles, used sport wt instructions.
projects.name: Green Socks (for Jason)

projects.notes: Really nice easy/predictable colorwork, full chart in the pattern making things even easier - I love this pattern.
projects.name: Endpaper Mitts

projects.notes:
I’m knitting a wedding shawl 3 months before my wedding because I am a sucker for exactly this kind of punishment.

Notes…

I made a few changes to the pattern for symmetry reasons as per this post:

Changed all the SK2Ps in Chart 1 and 2 (and the gauge swatch) to ”sl 2 as if to k2tog, psso”s. On Chart 3, there are a bunch of them that clearly mean to lean the opposite way of some k3togs - those I left as SK2Ps. (That is, I only changed: 13,53, 1,59, 13,67, and 1,67.)

For the Inc7 in Dec3, I worked: (k1, p1)x3, k

Right before Chart 1, I knit a row of plain knits.

I didn’t do any beadwork.

9/3: Chart 3, row 42: brain and hands threatening to revolt. Desire to knit: 0.

9/10: Finished Chart 3, cruising right along over the edging, love of knitting/shawls totally renewed. 13/56 repeats. Maybe by the end of this weekend!

9/17: DONE!

projects.name: Jen's Fetching

projects.notes:
I worked the cable pattern one more time around to make them a little longer.

My first project with cables! I made the finger bit longer on the left hand by accident because I fail at direction reading. The directions for the cable were very clear, but other parts of this pattern confused me quite a bit. Assumptions are made late in the game (‘needle 2’ = what?), and the thumbs in particular threw me for a loop. But I think I’ll still use this pattern again, I liked it.
projects.name: Framed Cable Fingerless Mitts

projects.notes:
Used US 5/6 needles (instead of 7/8) to get gauge.

1/18/12: It’s working! I am knitting a sweater!
1/29/12: Finished the body!
2/11/12: DONE! Woo hoo! Pictures tomorrow in daylight!

Modifications:

Body
Used the larger needle for the initial ribbing (lazy).

Worked the pattern in the round.
Waist ribbing: both the front and back ribbing started and ended with k2 - I assume to leave some stitches for seaming? I knit the back starting and ending with p2, instead, so the 2x2 rib was preserved.

Knit the waist shaping increases/decreases at 4” (instead of 2”).

Knit the front/back up to almost 19.75” instead of 14”. I have a long torso and I wanted the bottom edge to hang lower on me, anyway. Note that measuring directly over the cable it was only a smidge over 18” - the cabling makes it a little shorter. Since it’s in the front, that’s actually kinda desirable and looks nice!

Did the increases/decreases for the back and front (for armholes) exactly as written for the size.

Sleeves
CO an extra 2sts to even out the k2p2 rib (since I’m going in the round and not seaming the sleeves) and because I like the ribbed part of sleeves to be wide. I decreased (k2tog) twice when switching to stockinette.

I went for 7.75” after the 2” before doing the first increase for the sleeves, because it was looking nice and wide and my arms are pretty spindly down by the wrists. Didn’t do the last incease at all (stopped at 52 around).

Total length of sleeve before decreasing for sleeve cap: 22”.

Collar
Picked up 39sts on each side of back of neck.

Quit the short-rows when there were 18 sts left on each side (instead of 12) out of ‘omg, want to be done’ laziness and a slight preference for not-quite-so-tall collars.
projects.name: My <3st Sweater

projects.notes:
I’m afraid this entry is a little odd looking because I made so many hats (9 girl hats, 10 guy hats: 19 hats!) - I made two primary sorts, the “guy sort”:

1x1 rib around, decrease by p3tog every 10, then 9, 8, etc.

And the “girl sort”

No rib, knit around (makes the cute rolled brim), decrease by k2tog every 10, 9, 8, etc.

It took me ages! I had 12 done by Christmas, the last 6 had to wait a little while I scrambled to catch up, and my own hat didn’t come off the needles for quite awhile after.

I may never knit a hat again. Or anything orange.
projects.madeFor: All of my relatives (from one set of grandparents down) - 17 hats!

projects.notes:
Yarn: A big puffy skein of 100% acrylic bulky yarn, not sure the actual brand. CO 44 for Hat 2 and 40 for 3, casting on the amount the pattern suggested made for HUGE hats. These are still huge. My yarn is probably too big.

Progress:

10-11-10: Finished Hat 1, CO Hat 2.
10-13-10: Finished Hat 2.
Sometime in Nov?: Started, finished Hat 3 (not pictured, but looks exactly the same)

The other hats (in second pic) used a different pattern.

projects.name: White and Pink Lacy Socks

projects.notes:
My mom gets cold faster than anybody in the world - she’s one of the few people I know who doesn’t want to go swimming on a 90 degree day. So, for mother’s day, I knit her a supersoft, superthick snuggly coat.

If my end result doesn’t look like Hip to Knit’s, it’s my fault: I knit it way too large and had to improvise in places to make it work. The pattern was easy enough that even a not-so-great knitter like myself could do such a thing. My only complaint is doing the body of the coat in three pieces - totally not necessary! One would’ve worked just fine!

From Hip To Knit:

Your needles will fly using a super chunky yarn for this coat. The basic silhouette makes it easy to change the style from traditional to dramatic just by using a different textured yarn or varying the length. The sizing gives a slim-fitting look. If you like to layer, increase the size.
projects.name: Mom's Merino Coat

projects.notes: Baby Girl G is due in Nov. and needs a really cute tiny sweater, obviously. I even have good colors on hand. I’m going to do this one first before I start Kyra’s so I can get an idea of gauge/size, since I’m using the same pattern (different yoke variations, though).
projects.name: Baby Girl's Sweater

projects.notes:
Shooting for 18 or 24 months, which is technically outside the pattern’s specifications, but I knit big (and can use a larger yarn, maybe?)

I’m going to try to follow the advice of modder here to enlarge it a little bit:

http://www.ravelry.com/projects/vichageman/steps-to-stran...
